author: EitherToe
body:
We are all in here for money, not for political garbage on what's right or wrong. Ignore the Reddit stupidity of "HurRrH Durrrrr, cHIna BAd" therefore stock go down. We see JP Morgan pull "I did not take a bribe" but here we are betting on them or some other unethical company. Didi even has Goldman Sachs, Apple and Uber buy-in/management/oversight. Alibaba has big names like Charlie Munger buying stock, most people wouldn't bet against these people/companies.

Big tech USA is never going to win in Asia, this makes no sense. People here who think the Chinese government is going to let AWS or Microsoft run its software have done no research. A market of 1.4 billion, expecting to reach a greater GDP in 5 or so years is going to open its legs for the US? Let that sink in for a moment, the richest people in the US are owners of large US companies and supported by the US government. Is China dumb enough to let Amazon in and give them a free business that can't be controlled? Huawei failed outside of China but it's going to be building Chinese IoT infrastructure just like Cisco, Salesforce, AWS etc. 

China already has its big tech equivalent, some of them turning volumes higher than their US counterparts. I won't push people to either side, just present some arguments. You bet on what you think will actually make you money given your risk tolerance.

author: Daredizzle
body:
Do you use Salesforce? It's been built upon itself for two decades and is a really necessary and clunky solution consolidating data. They've been keeping themselves alive by acquiring company after company which is all they have going for them. They've spread themselves so thin over hundreds of different services you can purchase to run your business on THEIR platform. If you ever want to try new software, you better hope they integrate with SFDC because you're so unfortunately entrenched that the amount of money you'd have to spend to get out from under Salesforce is too high. You're stuck. And you may have had 5 different Salesforce admins who all had their own opinions on how it should be set up and automated and odds are good no one has ever done any clean up efforts. So instead of smooth sailing, you've got thousands of orphaned records that get in the way of reporting, and your marketing and sales automations because they'll all get tossed in the mix too. 

Not a single person in tech likes using Salesforce. Not one.

author: Summebride
body:
I have low confidence in cab companies' abilities. 

However, on paper, it's not inconceivable.  

Uber is essentially an app with a map and a match-up algorithm, not different than say a dating app.  It's a smooth enough interface that includes a payment and review system.  That's it.  

I don't see why someone couldn't code basically the same app.  Like say a cab company owner hires a few decent programmers.  Or a speculative software company writes the app and the licenses it out to cab companies the same way a jillion different CRM saas companies sell their mediocre customer service ticketing systems to everyone.  

Uber interface but without the actual headache of contracting drivers, being liable for anything, etc.  Just selling a software service and skimming a few percent off every dollar spent.

author: Daredizzle
body: As someone who works near the CRM space in tech, I honestly wouldn't bank on Salesforce that hard. There is a pretty solid collection of tech startups all cusping on IPO that are trying to end Salesforce as a requirement to run a business. But that's just me.

author: Brown_Coat_Black_Hat
body:
I'm not a fan of FB, meaning, I am not a power or casual user of any of their products. But here are the opportunities in front of FB.

1. Instagram is the fastest growing social platform outside US
2. They haven't started to monetize WhatsApp yet
3. VR today is what EV was 10-15 years ago. But if you actually use a VR headset you would realize the potential. It's not just entertainment and workouts. It's gonna change how we do our day jobs.
4. FB and it's products are ideal customer service (CRM) channels for brands. A lot of companies are already consolidating their existing channels in to messenger.
5. Facebook pay (monetization within FB platform)
6. Premium paid services like Twitter
7. FB commerce is just getting started
8. B2B (workplace products)

author: JungAndReckless6
body:
My take on valuation solely consists of the old Peter Lynch quote, “Investing in stocks is an art, not a science, and people who’ve been trained to rigidly quantify everything are at a disadvantage.” Another historical example was Massachusetts banning their residents from buying the Apple ipo because it was priced at 90x earnings and they thought the valuation would offer investors poor returns. The rules are constantly changing.

In my mind, it’s always been far more important to maintain cash flow into my portfolio and invest in super high quality management in expanding markets that should compound quite well for decades. If I believe NET is a 500b company in 15-20 years, there’s little reason to fuss about valuation, especially when it’s such an imprecise art. I understand it being more difficult getting in now, as my cost basis is significantly lower in most of the companies you mentioned (low 40’s in NET for example) but you really just need to commit to it.

I also found it interesting that during the huge growth sell off, stocks like NET and CRWD didn’t pull back as hard as a PTON ROKU or TDOC (all 5 of which I own) and they immediately made new highs, saw huge institutional accumulation, and saw some crazy volume. People want to own these stocks, and valuation can’t reflect the qualitative.

Also, some of the items in your watchlist are cheaper than your portfolio btw, PINS ETSY CRM all have a fwd PE of 50-60 which is considerably lower than everything in your portfolio aside from the mega caps and probably CLF.

I own CRWD NET ABNB PINS ETSY PTON SQ SOFI TSLA TDOC of everything you mentioned, and like most of the others.

author: hmchugh98
body: TLDR:  AvePoint is unusual in that it went public as a profitable company. Founded in 2001 as a provider of backup technology for Microsoft Exchange, the company has since become a major provider of SaaS technology for a wide swath of the Microsoft environment with 2020 revenue of $152 million, of which 75 percent is recurring revenue. The company estimates 2021 revenue to reach $194 million, of which over 80 percent will be recurring. We’re one of those rare SaaS, high-growth, but profitable, companies out there. There’s only seven other public companies like us trading on Wall Street today that have at least $150 million in revenue and at least 25 percent year-over-year growth, and that has at least 10 percent EBITDA profit margins. So that makes us quite unique. [We] have about $258 million cash on the balance sheet with no debt. We’re already multi-cloud. We follow the customer. Most customers today are multi-cloud. So we already have a product for Google Workspace. We have SaaS backup for Salesforce. And we can also already support Box and Dropbox. Customers today are multi-cloud. They may use Microsoft 365 for their office work, for their email, but they could be using Box or Dropbox file share, they could be using Salesforce for CRM, and even AWS for compute.

author: interrobangbros
body:
I’d venture to guess having >50 individual stock positions is somewhat rare for the average retail investor and >100 and very rare. That’s why you’ll get people who see “I have 100 positions” who instantly respond with “lol you’ve only built an ETF.” I’ve had plenty of people tell me that when I’ve mentioned how many positions I have. They say I’m diversified too much with the added risk of picking stocks. What they fail to ask if what are my holdings in. Currently, nearly 3/4 of my portfolios are in IT, consumer discretionary, and health care. I’m far from diversified. I also only have 29 stocks that are in SPY and 19 that are in QQQ. I am seeking response risk since I plan to be invested for 30+ more years. 

Just realized I’m rambling about me lol. In regards to your positions, I’ll stick with what I originally said. Sell anything you don’t have 100% conviction in. It doesn’t have to be a mass selling. You could do it over 6-12 months or something. I have a Sell Watchlist that I occasionally add positions to that I’m wavering on. I’ll pay a bit more attention to them, news around them, their earnings, investor call, etc. to see if my investment thesis still holds. If it doesn’t, I sell. A stock usually sits on that watchlist for 3-6 months before I sell it or decide I still want to be invested. It works for me. Maybe something like that would work for you and help you pare down from 150 to only the companies you really want to own. 

I perused your list. I don’t recognize some and don’t have the time to look them up now but my 2 cents on a few that aren’t in your keep section:

I own and wouldn’t consider selling: APPN, CRWD, ETSY, ISRG, MELI, SE, SQ, ZS, AMT, 

I own and wouldn’t consider selling but would understand why someone else would: APPH, FSLY, NIO, SNOW, TDOC, 

I don’t own CRM but I expect I will soon. 

Of the ones I mentioned above, MELI and ISRG are two of my highest conviction holdings. MELI in particular. It’s my 3rd largest position. They are an incredible company growing shockingly fast (hello Mercado Pago!) and they aren’t even an 80B MC company yet. I could see them 5x in the next 10 years.

author: foyerhead
body:
I agree with what you said! Regardless of valuation, good companies in expanding sectors will move up over time. I guess I’m a little worried that jumping in at a rich valuation would result in a lower than average market return - or rather the opportunity cost of not getting on the ground floor of a multibagger(even though it’s a crapshoot)

I also believe that value isn’t dead, of course finding good companies with good business models and management is important, but you can also try to get the best price that you think you can get. I don’t mean wait and hold cash for years hoping it drops to a certain price point, but to look for the best opportunities that you believe in is the future and providing you the best possible returns as well. 

There’s just so many companies with great tailwinds for the future, it’s pretty much impossible for me to invest in all of them! So I’m picking a few that I believe with give me the most bang for my buck (I think anyways)

On the topic of Etsy, I like the two acquisitions that they made but last quarter they also said about 30% of their revenue from sales was from masks. I wanted to get in when it sat at 160 but I didn’t feel strongly enough before it jumped. I’d like to see a few more consistent quarters to get enough conviction to invest in them. 

Same thing with PINS, they got a huge bump from COVID but I’m sort of skeptical of how much they can grow, since I believe that it’s a more niche social media platform than say a Facebook. Again I’d like to observe a bit more and see what direction they’re headed before I jump in.

I’ll look into CRM a bit more! It’s been a while so I forgot while I didn’t get in

author: WikiSummarizerBot
body:
**[California_High-Speed_Rail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_High-Speed_Rail)** 
 
 >California High-Speed Rail (CAHSR or CHSR) is a publicly funded high-speed rail system under construction in the U.S. state of California. It is projected to connect the Anaheim Regional Transportation Intermodal Center in Anaheim and Union Station in Downtown Los Angeles with the Salesforce Transit Center in San Francisco via the Central Valley, providing a one-seat ride between Union Station and San Francisco in 2 hours and 40 minutes, a distance of 380 miles (610 km). Future extensions (in Phase 2) are planned to connect southward to stations in San Diego County via the Inland Empire, as well as northward to Sacramento.

author: Jerzup

author: pennyether
body:
Best in breed for what they do, and every enterprise company is going to shift to using their software at one point or another.  Just like salesforce became the ubiquitous CRM for sales, Coupa will be ubiquitous on the finance/expense side.  Huge addressable market, very sticky, and they have a huge amount of momentum.  The product itself is pretty good (haven't used it, but read many reviews).

A bonus feature of their software.. when you use it, you get access to their community and AI. So, like, imagine you are sourcing something on your supply chain from XYZ, it'll tell you "many Coupa members are seeing missed shipments from XYZ, consider using ABC instead".

Basically a private review/rating/etc platform for the users.. but also AI that tracks orders, dates received, payment info, etc, and can automatically detect patterns from vendors/locations/etc (across ALL Coupa users, not just your company) and notify you.  Like... imagine the AI telling you "hey, you could probably only pay $X for this item, that's what others are paying!" or "this vendor has been shipping late recently", etc

Bear thesis is typical for that of a high growth company. A lot of their success is priced in. As far as growth goes, it's probably my top pick.

author: Nosefuroughtto
body:
I find it odd to consider Amazon like Standard Oil. SO derived it’s monopolistic power through acquisitions of rival refineries and distributors; purely horizontal integration, followed by outright price fixing.

Amazon is absolutely massive, but the growth method and diversity of markets they participate in distinguishes them from old trust oriented monopolies. I’m terms of AWS, the majority of growth was organic, and would not have ran afoul of antitrust law back in its hay day, such as when US v. Aluminum Co. of America was prevailing law.

An attempt to break up Amazon by business segment would probably fail due to the shift since the 70’s from Per Se Antitrust violations to the Rule of Reason. They aren’t dominating any given sector to the point that a court could likely prove anti-consumer behavior, which has increasingly become the prime factor.

Online shopping has a fairly rich market with Walmart, Home Depot, Best Buy, wayfair, etc.; physical stores obviously have Walmart and target being dominant; subscription services are still beaten by Netflix and Google, with Disney catching up fast; AWS competes with Oracle, Microsoft snd Google.

Overall I think the justifications for breaking up Amazon are weak in light of the method of growth, the fact that they aren’t shutting out competitors in any given industry right now, and our much more consumer viewpoint focus on antitrust enforcement.

author: HulksInvinciblePants
body:
>Good thing you can share your wisdom then, oh eternal oracle of the market.

Hmmm. I'm don't recall trying to predict when the market will crash and I post quite a bit, when I'm qualified to do so. My advice this time was making users aware of how bad this post was and how illiterates most this sub is. 

>Surely you know more then Dalio, what books have you written?

L. Ron Hubbard and Cosby wrote books too. That's a pretty low bar. 

>Gold is a old-school store of value by definition and as we saw in 2020 (amongst others) a great asset during times of uncertainty and crashes. Buy it during calm times, sell during fearful times.

Yeah, that's not accurate. Gold is not a hedge, its a portfolio diversifier. It's market correlation is 0.02, which is an unattached, positive number...not the large negative correlation you would hope for from a hedge. It did absolutely nothing during the dot-com bubble and probably hurt most investors that held during 2020.

author: aimaguru
body:
Yeah I'm not the oracle for ya when it comes to trying to time the market :)   


I've been mostly right on my directional plays but wrong too many times to count on "oh I'll just sell here and up my position on the way down" or "this is DEFINITELY never going higher than this" (cries in AMC)  


One framework I've seen (maybe rementioned on Fatty's DD) is would you be more upset about selling at X and it runs up to \[price target\] or holding and it dropping to \[your worst case thesis\].   


Personally (my risk tolerance and thesis re: ATOS, not necessarily yours) is that I like the stock enough and am enjoying the IV selling calls enough that, although I'd love a quick 4-10x pop, I'm okay with holding for the longer term, averaging down, and waiting for phase 3 and/or an acquisition down the line.

author: CodeMaitre
body:
ORCL One Year and 6 Month Chart - [https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg](https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg)

It has pretty much made its move, you'd be buying in the "sell" area statistically. You're correct, the buy zone is  always below regression trend (average) line in the middle, so you'd want to snag it if it goes back down to 75-80. Although its true downward potential is the blue -1 deviation line, so 70-73. Deviations change a little bit day to day as more price data is added but right now you'd be buying into an uptrend which is not very safe. You'd basically be betting to get the cherry on top running up to +1 deviations at 88-91.

author: Toys_R_Them
body:
Most of the new growth has been in tech, and tech rarely pays dividends, outside of some stalwarts like MSFT and ORCL.

A lot of those dividend payers are energy companies and REITs, who also underperformed for various pandemic-related reasons.

A portfolio that high in dividends is typically recommended for older people, who need current income and downside protection in case of economic swings, and could care less about potential growth of their portfolio decades from now.

author: OfficialTestikills
body:
I personally invest heavily in Web3 crypto's and crypto projects that help run and keep these crypto's decentralised. 

What's a web3 crypto? These aren't to be confused with junk like Bitcoin that thinks it is a store of value or will become the new financial system, web3 crypto is literally creating the next stage in internet where you don't need to worry about your companies information / personal information / classified documents being stored on a server that is owned and managed by other companies. Web3 splits this up between 100's of validators that all talk to each other and keep this decentralised and secure from attacks. 

There's also ones creating the future of finance. No longer do you need to get bent over by huge interest rates and banks fucking people over whenever they feel like it. DEFI is run by liquidity pools, people like you and I who store our money with the service and as a result get a percentage of the interest rates. These rates always remain low and competitive and go to the people rather than the big banks.

Then you have oracles that power the decentralisation. Oracles gain info from many sources and feed it to the protocol to offer decentralised information. For easy laymans terms, if I wanted a weather oracle, it would gather weather data from 1000's weather stations and news outlets, work out the average forecast and feed that to my protocol. This means my protocol is giving the users the most accurate non-biased information. Just as a high-level. 

So how do you make money from this? Well, let's look at Ethereum just as an example. Every single protect that runs on Ethereum has to pay "gas" fees on each transaction, this is paid in Ethereum. Ethereum already has 1000's of applications including VISA and MasterCard that constantly have a demand for Ethereum in order to operate and pay these gas fees. You as the investor holds the Ethereum they need and this creates supply and demand. Additionally, each time a company pays their gas fees, the gas is "burnt" (meaning Ethereum used to pay for the transaction is burnt) creating deflation. 

Ethereum is just one project, and not one that I personally even invest in that much, but it's one that I'm sure most people have heard of.   
If you want to look at getting some crypto while it's currently on a low and has huge potentially to be the future of a new decentralised internet feel free to use my exchange code. Swyftx is aussie based exchange and you get 20% off fees with my code, plus I get a kick back [https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner](https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner)

&#x200B;

Message me if you want to know more
